PhaseBanner.Content: This is a new service – your feedback will help us to improve it.

Hero.Heading: DfE Developer Hub
Hero.Intro: Build Education software using Department for Education APIs

Content.Body: 1. Create an account
Create an account with the DfE Developer Hub to gain access to APIs and their relevant subscription keys.
Go to create an account.
2. Register an application
Registering an application allows DfE to understand who is accessing our data and for what reasons. Once you have signed in go to Registering your application and follow the process

Registering an application is quick and easy and gives you access to a unique client identifier and secret(s) for use when calling DfE APIs. Using this client id and secret helps keep your applications and our data secure.
3. Subscribe to an API

In order to integrate with a DfE API you must first subscribe to the required API, so that you can get access to a subscription key. The subscription key is unique to each client for the DfE API. If you need to connect to multiple DfE APIs you must subscribe to each one.

You can subscribe to either the sandbox or production version of the API depending on where you are in your development process. It is advisable to subscribe to the sandbox API first to ensure your developed software is fully functional before moving it to production (utilising production subscription key).

Once you have registered your application you will be able to view your credential details and save them. Viewing your application details will allow you to click on the link Subscribe to APIs. Select the API you wish to integrate with and choose sandbox or production.
4. Getting subscription keys
Before any subscription keys are produced an internal process is carried out to grant access. Depending on the setup of the API this process can take up to a maximum of 3 working days.
Once your subscription request has been agreed an email notification will be sent out to the email address you have registered with.
To see the status of your request, go to API subscriptions select the API and the status will be shown.
The statuses are as follows:

Data: The subscription request has been made and is pending DfE approval
The subscription is ready for use. A primary and secondary subscription key is displayed along with the URL
The subscription has been reviewed by DfE and they have rejected your request. A rejection reason will be displayed
The subscription request has been cancelled by the user. DfE will not progress any further unless a new request is made
The subscription has been suspended. Contact support via the Support tab and complete the form to have the request unsuspended

Content.Body: 5. Redirect URLs
When you first register an application, you are required to provide a redirect URL. You can add and edit up to five redirect URLs by going to Redirect URLs
We use redirect URLs to send the user back to your application after successful (or unsuccessful) authorisation, prior to your application accessing user-restricted endpoints.

You must specify one redirect URL when you register your application, and also specify one redirect URL when you send your user to our authorisation endpoint. Multiple redirect URLs can be added at a later stage if required.

To protect your application from phishing attacks, the redirect URL you use for authorisation (in your call to DfE authorisation endpoint) must match one of those you specified when you registered your application.
6. Calling an API
Once all of the previous 5 steps have been completed you will have access to the required elements to make an API call

Body: The DfE API URL and endpoint
A unique client id and secret
A unique API subscription key
A registered redirect URL

Content.Body: If you require assistance in making the API calls, see our Tutorials
Introduction
Our APIs have 3 types of endpoint. Each endpoint has its own:

Body: Access level.
Authorisation token.
Authorisation procedure.

Body.Caption: Endpoint types and their required tokens

Data: OAuth 2.0 access token (subscription key needed) Generated using OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Grant
OAuth 2.0 access token (subscription key needed) Generated using OAuth 2.0 Authorisation Code Grant

Content.Body: As per the latest OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice DfE API's do not support implicit and password OAuth grant types.
Credentials
Your credentials are your client id and your client secret. Developer Hub supplies 2 active client secrets (primary and secondary) at any one time.
Credentials are used:

Body: To identify and authorise your application during each step of the journey.
When you test your application with sandbox APIs or run against the production APIs

Content.Body: Client id
Your client id is a unique identifier we create when you register your application on the Developer Hub.
Client secrets
Client secrets are unique passphrases that you generate to authorise your application. They are known only to your application and the authorising server.
The client secret is the equivalent of a password and should not be stored in plain text. Only store an encrypted version of the client secret to reduce the chance of it being compromised.
Rotate your client secret regularly
Rotate your application's client secret to shorten the period an access key is active, reducing the impact to your business if it is compromised.
To rotate your client secret:

Body: Once you register your application, your application is assigned two secrets (primary and secondary).
These secrets are usually valid for 2 years.
Use the primary secret along with the client id to integrate with DfE APIs.

If you need to rotate your primary secret, login to the Developer Hub and check that your secondary secret for the application has a reasonable amount of time remaining until expiry (e.g. 6 months at least).
Update your application to use the secondary secret.
Check that your application is working with the secondary secret.
Regenerate your primary secret.

Content.Body: Open access endpoints

These endpoints are the least restricted and service general data held by the department. These endpoints only require a subscription key to be passed and there is no requirement for an access token. These endpoints usually allow self-approval for subscriptions.
In this example, you'll access the Department for Education API 'DfE Information' endpoint.
This endpoint is least restricted so you can access it without an OAuth2.0 access token. You still need to subscribe and pass the subscription key.
Application-restricted endpoints
Application-restricted endpoints do not require authorisation from the end user. These endpoints do not give access to sensitive personal data.

We use the open standard OAuth 2.0 with the Client Credentials Grant to generate an access token. If the endpoint requires a scope, your application must include this scope when creating the access token. Along with the access token, a valid API subscription key is also required when accessing the API.
Read the API documentation authorisation rules for specific API endpoints.
The access token lasts for 1 hour. When it expires you must generate a new token.
User-restricted endpoints
These endpoints require specific authorisation from the end user and they generally give access to sensitive personal data.

We use the open standard OAuth 2.0 with the Client Credentials Grant. This allows the end users to grant authority to your application to interact with DfE on their behalf, without sharing their access credentials.

The end user authenticates directly with us using their IDAMS and DfE sign-in accounts, and grants authority for specific scopes. We then issue an OAuth 2.0 access token that’s specific to the end user. Your application passes the access token in subsequent API requests to user-restricted endpoints. Along with the access token, a valid API subscription key is also required when accessing the API.
For a working example of the 3 authorisation use cases, see the Tutorials section.
Before you start
All base URLs in these tutorials use the test environment.
All code snippets in these tutorials are in CSharp (C#). They use the RestSharp (opens in new tab) library for accessing HTTP resources.
You can find more code samples in our public GitHub repositories. They're available in:

Body: CSharp (opens in new tab)
Java (opens in new tab)
Node.js (opens in new tab)

Content.Body: Most of our APIs use HTTP verbs and a RESTful interface. You can find out more information on these online.
These tutorials use a simple DfE Information (example) API that exposes 3 endpoints:

Body.Caption: Endpoints exposed by DfE Information API

Content.Body: Getting your subscription keys
All the above endpoints require an API subscription key header. Before running any of these examples follow the steps below

Body: Create an account in the DfE Developer Hub.
Register your application which will integrate with the DfE APIs.
Copy your client id and secret details.
Subscribe to the ‘DfE Information’ API and choose sandbox environment.
This should provide you with a primary and secondary subscription key
Copy the primary key for below tests.

Content.Body: Accessing an open endpoint
In this example, you'll access the DfE Information API 'open-info' endpoint.
This endpoint does not require an authorisation header so you can access it without an access token. You are still required to send a subscription key (copied from above step).
Issue a GET request to:
https://oat-api-customerengagement.platform.education.gov.uk/DfE/open-info
Accessing an application-restricted endpoint
In this example, you will request an access token in your code (utilising your client id and client secret details) and then use it to access the DfE Information API 'application-info' endpoint.
See the authorisation section for information about requesting an Access token.
1. Go to the 'DfE Information' API documentation page and copy the OAuth token endpoint URL.
2. Request an OAuth 2.0 access token in your application code
3. Make a GET request to the ‘DfE Information’ API application-info endpoint:
https://oat-api-customerengagement.platform.education.gov.uk/DfE/application-info
This should give you a 'DfE department high level information' response.
Accessing a user-restricted endpoint
In this example, you will request an OAuth 2.0 access token in your code (utilising your client id and client secret details) and use it to access the DfE Information API 'user-info' endpoint.
The user restricted endpoints provide details on the API page about their authorisation endpoint. Follow steps below to obtain access token and then make a call to the endpoint.
Authorise user
To begin the flow, you'll need to get the user's authorisation. This step may include one or more of the following processes:

Body: Authenticating the user
Obtaining user consent for the requested permission level, unless consent has been previously given

Content.Body: To authorise the user, your app must send the user to the authorisation URL provided on the user-restricted API page. The scope details would also be provided on the specific API page.
1. Request an OAuth 2.0 authorisation code with the required scope
https://user-restricted-end-point -login/authorise?response_type=code&client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&redirect_uri=https://YOUR_APP/callback&scope=SCOPE&audience=API_AUDIENCE&state=STATE
As an example, your HTML snippet for your authorisation URL when adding login to your app might look like:
Sign In
The user will be redirected to the DfE Identity login screen. When they've submitted their credentials, they'll be asked to authorise your application to access the requested scope.
Once the user has granted the requested authority, we will return to your application via the redirect URL. We'll provide  an authorisation code as a query string parameter.
This authorisation code can then be exchanged for an OAuth 2.0 access_token and a refresh_token.
2. Exchange the OAuth 2.0 authorisation code for an access token
3. Make a GET request to the ‘DfE Information’ API user-info endpoint:
https://oat-api-customerengagement.platform.education.gov.uk/DfE/user-info
4. Refresh an expired OAuth 2.0 access_token
This exchanges a refresh_token for a new access_token (and a new refresh_token).

Body.Body: on this page

Body: Browser support for OAuth 2.0
Coding in the open
Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS)
Redirect URLs
TLS standards

Body.Body: Read the reference guide for actions you need to take to make sure your application integrates with DfE.
See the development practices for how to avoid your application failing without warning when DfE make changes.
Browser support for OAuth 2.0
The OAuth 2.0 authorisation journey is designed to work with most modern browsers as per the list specified on Designing for different browsers and devices, including mobile devices and tablets.
Coding in the open
The DfE Developer Hub, the underlying API Platform and some of the APIs are coded in the open, as per the GOV.UK Digital Service Standard (opens in a new tab).
The source code is available at https://github.com/hmrc (opens in a new tab). For more details, please contact us.
Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS)

The API Platform does not support cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) (opens in a new tab). It is therefore not possible to call our APIs from client-side code within a web browser, for example using Ajax.
Redirect URLs
We use redirect URLs to send the user back to your application after successful (or unsuccessful) authorisation, prior to your application accessing user-restricted endpoints.
You must specify a redirect URL when you create your application, and also specify one redirect URL when you send your user to our authorisation endpoint.

To protect your application from phishing attacks, the redirect URL you use for authorisation (in your call to /oauth/authorize) must match one of those you specified when you created your application.
Also, you must use the same redirect URL when exchanging your authorisation code for an access token (in your call to /oauth/token) that you used for authorisation (in your call to /oauth/authorize).
Examples
Examples of valid (and invalid) redirect URLs are:

Data:
Valid - when creating your application, you can use the full redirect URL or a partial URL, for example:

https://www.example.com/auth-redirect

https://www.example.com

When calling our authorisation endpoint, your redirect URL must be percent-encoded, for example:

https%3A%2F%2Fwww.example.com%2Fauth-redirect
Invalid - uses HTTP, not HTTPS (HTTP is OK for installed applications - see example below)
Invalid - is a relative URL, not an absolute URL
Invalid - uses an IP address, not a DNS name
Invalid - as explained in OAuth 2.0 for installed applications
Valid - as explained in OAuth 2.0 for installed applications
Valid - as explained in OAuth 2.0 for installed applications

Body.Body: TLS standards
DfE APIs are only accessible over Transport Layer Security (TLS). For example, URLs that begin with https://
Applications must support TLS 1.2 or higher to avoid known weaknesses in previous versions.

The DfE Developer Hub uses DevOps practices, iterative development, continuous integration, continuous testing and continuous delivery to make hundreds of small changes to the production environment each year.
Follow the development practices to make sure your application is not affected by the changes we make.
How to avoid your application failing without warning
You should avoid unintentionally tightly coupling your application to DfE.
Tight coupling means a set of systems are dependent on one another. Making a change in a tightly coupled setup requires changes to both systems.
Loose coupling reduces dependencies and ensures non-breaking changes have no impact on your application.
HTTPS certificates can change
The DfE Developer Hub’s HTTPS certificates can change. This includes the leaf certificate, intermediary certificates and the root certificate.
Warning - If you import any DfE specific certificates into your keystone or load balancer, then your application may fail to connect when certificate changes occur.
Use a global root CA keystore and do not pin DfE  specific certificates
IP addresses can change

You might need to configure your network so your software can access our API Platform and token generation. If your software is installed on end user devices, they might also need to configure their own network
We have fixed domain names, but cannot provide static IP addresses, so you need to configure your network access in your proxy, not your firewall.
Configure your proxy to allow full access to the following domains, including HTTP GET, POST, PUT and DELETE
For testing in sandbox:

Body: URL TO BE FINALISED

Body.Body: For production use:

Body: URL TO BE FINALISED

Body.Body: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS)

The DfE Developer Hub does not support cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) (opens in a new tab). It is not possible to call our APIs from client-side code within a web browser, for example using Ajax
Version 1 issued 18 August 2020

These terms of use explain what you can expect from us and what weexpect from you when registering and operating software services that consume DfE Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) hosted on the DfE Developer Hub. They do not create a legal relationship between HMRC and any software developer.
We reserve the right to remove your access to the Developer Hub and its APIs temporarily or permanently.

These terms may change from time to time and we will let you know when this happens. For major changes you may need to re-accept these terms of use, but for minor changes we will assume you agree to the changes unless we hear from you.
If you have any questions ask for support.
Background checks
We may carry out basic background checks on your organisation. They include checking:

Body: information held by Companies House
your website

Body.Body: What you can expect from us
We will:

Body: give you at least 6 months' notice of changes affecting any stable APIs
make sure any minor changes made to stable APIs are backwards compatible
provide reasonable notice of changes affecting beta APIs, which can change fairly frequently
warn you before we retire an API

Body.Body: What we expect from you
We take the protection of customer data seriously. We expect you to do the same by following data protection law and protecting users in line withthe:

Body: National Cyber Security Centre's Digital Service Security (opensin a new tab)
National Cyber Security Centre's Guidance for secure development and deployment (opens in a new tab)
Transport Layer Security principles for protecting data (opens in a new tab)
General Data Protection Regulation – GDPR (opens in a new tab)
Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003 – as amended (opens in a new tab)
Equality Act 2010 (opens in a new tab)
Information Commissioner's Office (opens in a new tab)
Data Protection Act 2018 (opens in a new tab)

Body.Body: You must also follow these acts and regulations if they're changed or replaced.
Accessing data
You must give your users access to their data. We may also ask to access their data if we open an investigation.
If you withdraw a piece of software or a user stops using it, you must let them retrieve and export all their data so they can meet their obligations to us.
We recommend using multi-factor authentication to protect personal data.
Processing data
You may need to pay a data protection fee (opens in a new tab) if your software processes personal data

You must help us protect our users' confidential data by sending us particular types of user audit data which we will record. Our APIs provide HTTP headers that you can use to pass this audit data to us. See how to do this under fraud prevention.
To find out if header information is mandatory for an API that you use, read its API documentation.
Storing data
If you store and process their personal data, you must tell users:

Body: what personal data you'll be processing and what you'll use it for
that you're responsible for protecting their data
if you intend to store their data outside the European Economic Area
your lawful basis (opens in a new tab) for processing their personal data

Body.Body: If you need users' consent to store and process their personal data you'll need to follow GDPR rules on obtaining consent (opens in a new tab).
If you store or process data outside the European Economic Area, you must follow GDPR guidance on international transfers (opens in a new tab).
Service standard
Your software must take into account the Digital Service Standard.
Accessibility
You must:

Body: meet W3C's Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (opens in a new tab) at a minimum level of AA if your software's web-based, or W3C's guidelines for mobile software (opens in a new tab)
give us evidence that your software meets the guidelines, if we ask for it
ask for support if you have any concerns meeting these guidelines

Body.Body: Advertising and marketing
Any advertising that appears in your software must follow both:

Body: Advertising Standards Authority Codes (opens in a new tab)
UK marketing and advertising laws (opens in a new tab)

Body.Body: You must not use advertising that promotes:

Body: adult themes
dating
gaming

Body.Body: You cannot share personal data for marketing without users' consent, as defined in the Direct Marketing Guidance PDF from the Information Commissioner's Office (opens in a new tab)
Licence agreements
You must make the terms of the licence agreement between you and your users clear to them.
Security
You must:

Body: check software for vulnerabilities through secure development and pre-release testing
check open source or reused proprietary code using resources like the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (opens in a new tab) database
react quickly if you find vulnerabilities in your code
have a patching policy in place

Body.Body: Your re-releases and upgrades should also follow secure development practices and pre-release testing.
We recommend following the security principles of:

Body: the National Cyber Security Centre (opens in a new tab)
National Cyber Security Centre's Guidance for secure development and deployment (opens in a new tab)
the Open Web Application Security Project (opens in a new tab)
Cyber Essentials or Cyber Essentials Plus certification (opens in a new tab)

Body.Body: Suspicious activity
We expect you to look out for and block suspicious attempts to access or manipulate user accounts.
Support
You must give software support to your users. If you need help ask for support.
Content to be finalized before Beta

Auth.Warning: You need an account to view this API.
You need an account to view applications.

Production.Copy: After testing in the sandbox, you can apply for production credentials.

Auth.Warning: You need an account to register applications.

Body.Body: To start using our RESTful APIs with your application, you'll need to:

Body: Add it to our test environment (sandbox).
Choose which sandbox APIs you want to use.
Get credentials your application needs to interact with our APIs.

Body.Body: Make sure your application complies with our terms of use
If you have not already done so:

Body: Find out which RESTful and XML APIs you can use.
Read up on authorisation.
Familiarise yourself with the <a class='govuk-link' href='https://oauth.net/2/' rel='noreferrer noopener' target='_blank'>OAuth 2.0 specification (opens in new tab).

Body.Body: Using DfE in the name
Using DfE or making any reference to DfE as part of the name is not allowed and will result in your application being rejected.
Existing names
The name of your application can't be the same or similar to the nameof an application which has already requested production credentials on the Developer Hub.
'The same' means a name that's either identical, or where the only difference is punctuation or a special character.
Exceptions
This doesn't apply if it meets both these conditions:

Body: The name will be part of a group with an existing application withthe same or similar name.
The admins of the existing application give you permission to use the name.

Body.Body: Trademarked and registered names
Your application's name must not be the same or similar to a trademarked name that's registered by another business outside the DfE Developer Hub.
Offensive names
Your name can't contain offensive words or phrases.
Misleading names

Your application's name cannot mislead users into believing your application has special status or power. Such names might associate your application with government, local authorities, or institutions. For example, the Royal Tax App could be misleading.
Removal from the Developer Hub
We have the right to delete your application at any point, for any reason.
Content to be finalized before Beta

Content.Body: In order for your application to integrate with a DfE API you must first subscribe to the required API, so that you can get access to a subscription key.
Before any subscription keys are produced an internal process is carried out to grant access. Depending on the setup of the API this process can take up to a maximum of 3 working days.

You can subscribe to either the sandbox or production version of the API depending on where you are in your development process. It is advisable to subscribe to the sandbox API first to ensure your developed software is fully functional before moving it to production (utilising production subscription key).
We only show you a new client secret once to help keep your data secure.
Rotate your client secret regularly
Rotate your application's client secret to shorten the period an access key is active, reducing the impact to your business if it is compromised.
To rotate your client secret:

Body: Regenerate one of your client secrets
Update your application to use the updated client secret.
Check that your application is working with the updated client secret.

Content.Body: You can add and edit up to five redirect URLs using the link below.

To protect your application from phishing attacks, the redirect URL you use for authorisation (in your call to DfE authorisation endpoint) must match one of those you specified when you registered your application.

Body.Body: Complete this short form to ask a question, for example, about:

Body: General enquiry
Issue with the website
Issue with an API
Other

Body.Body: and our Support Team will get back to you within 2 working days. You can also check our reference guide for answers.
We will get back to you within 2 working days.
Continue to the home page.

DeleteAccount.Heading: Delete account
DeleteAccount.Copy: You can ask us to delete your account and we will respond within 2 working days.

Cookies.Page: Details about cookies on DfE Developer Hub

Body.Body: The DfE Developer Hub puts small files (known as 'cookies') onto your computer to collect information about how you browse the site. Find out more about the cookies we use, what they're for and when they expire.
Cookies that measure website use

We use Google Analytics software (Universal Analytics) to collect anonymised information about how you use the Developer Hub. We do this to help make sure the site is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements to the site and to government digital services.
We do not allow Google to use or share the data about how you use this site.
Google Analytics software collects information about how you use GOV.UK. This includes IP addresses. The data is anonymised before being used for analytics processing
Google Analytics stores information about:

Body: how you got to the site
the pages you visit on the Developer Hub and how long you spend on them
what you click on while you're visiting the site Google Analytics sets the following cookies.

Data: These help us count how many people visit by tracking if you've visited before
These help us count how many people visit by tracking if you've visited before

Body.Body: We also set our own cookie to understand how people move through the site:

Data: This lets us know the next page you visit, so we can make journeys better

Body.Body: JavaScript detection
We measure how many people visiting the Developer Hub are using JavaScript, so that the site works for as many users as possible.

Data: This tells us if you are browsing while running JavaScript

Body.Body: Strictly necessary cookies

These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms.    Youcan set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

Data: Set by websites run on the Windows Azure cloud platform. It is used for load balancing to make sure the visitor page requests are routed to the same server in any browsing session.

Body.Body: Cookies message

You may see a banner when you visit the Developer Hub inviting you to accept cookies or review your settings. We'll set cookies so that your computer knows you've seen it and not to show it again, and also to store your settings.

Data: Lets us know that you've saved your cookie consent settings

Body.Body: Your personal information

This privacy policy relates to the information we store about you as a Developer Hub user. It does not relate to the privacy of the end users of any application you develop; under our terms of use you are responsible for the information stored by your application.

We collect certain information about you when you use the Developer Hub and APIs. This page explains what kind of personal information we collect, how it's protected and how you can find out about it.
If we change this privacy policy, we’ll notify all Developer Hub users by email.
GDPR lawful basis
We hold information about you as a software developer on the lawful basis of “public task” so that we can run the Developer Hub as a service to you.
What personal information do we hold about you?
When you use the Developer Hub, we collect:

Body: your personal details including name, email address and optionally the name of your organisation
information about your applications and the email addresses of those of your colleagues with access to them
your IP address, and details of which version of web browser you use
information on how you use our site, based on cookies and page tagging techniques
any questions, queries or feedback you leave, including your email address, if you contact our support team

Body.Body: How we use and share your data

We use this information to create and administer user accounts on the Developer Hub. The information you give us will be used in a customer relationship management tool to help us manage our customer service obligations. We do not share this information with anyone else.

We store your information so that your user account on the Developer Hub can function correctly, and so we can administer that access via our approval process for issuing production credentials. This includes sending you service updates and notices.
We undertake the following checks for application approvals:

Body: Companies House – to check the status of the business is “Active”.
LinkedIn – to check the business digital footprint
Twitter – to check the business digital footprint.
Company website – to check the business digital footprint but also for reassurance we are dealing with a valid developer.
Sandbox testing – to check/validate the developer has conducted sufficient testing of the API before being provided access to the live environment.

Body.Body: We delete your personal information when your user account is deleted, and keep audit records of your user account activity for up to 6 years.
How we protect your personal information
We comply with the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
We will:

Body: tell you why the information is needed
only ask for what's needed
make sure no one has access to it who shouldn't
only keep the information for as long as it's needed
not make it available for commercial use

Body.Body: Third party integration
We use third party software to help us improve your experience on this website including Google Analytics.
The following information may be collected about your device and browser and held so it cannot be used to identify who you are:

Body: device's IP address
device screen resolution
device type (unique device identifiers), operating system, and browser type
geographic location (city and country only)
preferred page display language
referring domain
pages visited
preferred language used to display the webpage
date and time when website pages were accessed
mouse events (movements, location and clicks)
keypresses

Body.Body: You can opt out of Google Analytics by installing their Opt out Browser Add-on (opens in a new tab).
Handling your information
Our staff are trained in handling information and understand how important it is to protect personal and other sensitive information.
Asking to see your information

You can ask to see the personal information we hold about you. To help locate the information you want and deal with your request more quickly, you should make your GDPR request to the DfE office advised by our support team. You should address your request to the Data Protection Officer.
There is no charge.
Sometimes we can withhold information, for example, to protect national security.
Your GDPR right to be forgotten
You can ask us to delete all the information we hold about you, if you no longer wish to be a user of the Developer Hub. To do this contact our support team.
Children
The Developer Hub is not for use by children under the age of 16. We do not knowingly hold personal information on children under the age of 16.
